channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.dc:subject: Weekly collections

item.title: Reverse Positions
item.description: This week was Python only unlike when we get Perl as well. As always, the blog is dedicated to Python. Keep it up great work.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Reverse the Position to Equalise the Group
item.description: Never under-estimate the power of JavaScript. Line by line discussion is very handy too. Highly recommended.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #318
item.description: Getting more than what is asked is always handy with detailed task analysis. Well done.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Repeat and reverse
item.description: When it comes to Perl regex, we get plenty of varieties. Thanks for the cool naration and DIY tool. Keep it up great work.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Group the Reverse Position
item.description: Musical theme post is back, you'll never get bored. Plenty of choices to pick. Highly recommended.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Find Twice and Reverse Once
item.description: Great discussion about backreferences to capture groups in regex. Not so easy to understand but the discussion made it so simple. Thanks for sharing knowledge.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 318
item.description: Obfuscated Perl? Well it is so close to that this time. Not easy to decode in first attempt. Keep sharing knowledge.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Short and to the point!
item.description: Raku one-liner with function chaining is so elegant and unbeatable. Great work, keep it up.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Reverse Groups
item.description: Are you PDL fan? Well even if you aren't this will blow your mind. Simply incredible.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Reverse Equals
item.description: CPAN friendly solution is my all time favourite, it makes the end result cute and compact. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Reverse Postition
item.description: Line by line discussion makes it super easy to follow the workflow. Bonus, you get the official word about each function used. Well done and keep it up.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: TWC318
item.description: Perl regex is once again showing the real power. Real gem is shared, cool.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Group Position Reversals
item.description: Perl only this week but enough to keep you busy with engaging narration. Keep it up great work.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 318
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Group Position" and "Reverse Equals" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 319
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Word Count" and "Minimum Common". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Map::Tube v4.09
item.description: Upgrade minimum Perl v5.14 for better Unicode support. Also few handy updates.
item.dc:subject: CPAN

item.title: Tree::DAG_Node V 1.34 uploaded to CPAN
item.description: Many thanx to Shawn Laffan for testing this version on Strawberry Perl. I test it on my Debian machine first of course. It took Shawn and myself a number of attempts to make all the test pass under the 2 types of OSes.
item.dc:subject: CPAN

item.title: How can I sort a nested hash by its nested hash's values?
item.description: This is very interesting question and solution is even more cooler, worth checking out.

item.title: Map::Tube Unicode
item.description: Map::Tube finally supports Unicode character in station and line names officially. Please give it a try.

item.title: Generate Fixtures for Rose::DB ORM
item.description: For all Rose::DB fans, this is for you, a very handy when it comes to generating fixtures for unit test.
item.dc:subject: Articles

item.title: Tech stack at booking.com
item.description: There was a time, Perl was ruling booking.com. It has changed now, checkout the discussion to find out the current state of affairs.
item.dc:subject: Announcements

item.title: #718 - Top Perl Companies
item.description:
Hi there,

Please accept my apology for sharing a crypto scam link in the 716th edition of the newsletter. Thanks to Gabor and Dave, it was removed straight away. I will be more cautious from now onwards, promise.

Recently, I stumbled upon a post titled "Top 11 Perl Services Companies in the World in 2025". Sadly, not a single one is based in my city London. There was a time, we had plenty! Still, it's not all bad. I was thrilled to see ActiveState on the list, the company behind ActiveState Perl.

In an earlier edition of the newsletter, I mentioned my wish to attend the Perl Toolchain Summit which is an invite-only annual event. I also shared my interest in contributing to the MetaCPAN project. To my absolute delight, that wish came true the very same day! I received an invitation from the organiser to join the Perl Toolchain Summit 2025, happening in Leipzig, Germany from May 1st to May 4th 2025. I didn't wait even a second to accept the invitation. It's truly an honour to be part of such a talented group.

In all the excitement, I've already booked my flight ticket to Berlin and from there I'll hop on a fast train to Leipzig. The last time, I visited Germany was back in 2018 when I attended the 20th German Perl Workshop in the city of Gummersbach. I even gave couple of talks and one of them being "Introduction to Map::Tube". After the event, I even shared my experience in this event report.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: Editorial
